SourceText: Today's tip is about caring for yourself.
In tough times like these, it's normal to feel overwhelmed. Remember, it is important to take a moment for yourself, no matter how small.
Taking care of yourself helps you be there for your children during tough times.
‚ñ∂Ô∏èPress play to learn 4Ô∏è‚É£tips on how to take care of yourself:
1Ô∏è‚É£ **REST**
2Ô∏è‚É£ **CONNECT**
3Ô∏è‚É£ **BREATHE**
4Ô∏è‚É£ **CARE**
Here are 4 tips on how to take care of yourself:
Even if rest looks different right now, try to rest when you can.
Take a few minutes between responsibilities to do something that helps you relax.
Connect with loved ones as often as you can.
Find someone you can talk to about how you are feeling.
Take a moment each day to listen to your breath as it goes in and out.
Losing your temper? Breathe in and out slowly five times.
Make sure to take care of yourself so you can feel better and be there for your family.
Remember to praise yourself each time you take steps to cope.
Thank you for joining us. Remember, you're doing the best you can. Be proud.
This tip is about making a routine for your children.
When we are in crisis, things can feel unfamiliar. Having routines helps your children feel safe and stable.
When you do the same things every day, it makes life more familiar for your children. It also makes them feel less worried and more secure.
‚ñ∂Ô∏èPress play to learn 3Ô∏è‚É£ tips on making routines to spend time together with your children:
1Ô∏è‚É£ **DO IT DAILY**
2Ô∏è‚É£ **PLAY EVERY DAY**
3Ô∏è‚É£ **PRACTISE BEING CALM**
Here are 3Ô∏è‚É£ tips on making routines to spend time together with your children:
Even when it feels hard, try to have some activities that you and your children do every day for yourself and your children.
If you can, daily routines like eating together and cleaning can help children feel safe, especially during uncertain times.
Try to set aside time to play or spend quality time with your children every day.
Playing with and talking to children for a few minutes every day helps them feel secure.
Ask children what they would like to do.
Listen to them, look at them, and give them your full attention.
Our children learn calmness and kindness from us.
Every day, try telling yourself a calming message.
Try ‚ÄúI can do this, I am trying my best.‚Äù
Small amounts of time can help children feel safe and loved.
After this lesson, you can type {PLAY} to get some activity ideas to do with children.
Here are some regular activities you might want to try to do with your children:
Eat one meal together
Getting ready to sleep
Exercise daily
Daily play activities
Thank you for joining us. Parenting is not always easy. Well done for doing the best you can.
This tip is about helping your children cope with crisis.
It is normal to be worried about your children, especially during tough times
Children might face emotions and challenges they don‚Äôt know how to handle.
There are things you can do to help them feel better now and make them stronger for the future.
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Press play to learn 3Ô∏è‚É£ tips on how you can support your children during tough times:
1Ô∏è‚É£ **LISTEN**
2Ô∏è‚É£ **PRAISE YOUR CHILDREN**
3Ô∏è‚É£ **PRAISE YOURSELF**
Here are 3Ô∏è‚É£ tips on how you can support your children during tough times:
Children may be scared, confused and angry. Simply being present and listening makes all the difference. They need your support.
Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling.
Tell them whatever they are feeling is okay, and give them comfort.
Ask children to help with day-to-day tasks, such as making food or cleaning.
Praise them for trying or doing well. This encourages helpful behaviour.
Praising children shows them that you notice and care.
Every day before you sleep, praise yourself for trying to help your children cope.
Thinking of even 1 thing you are proud of can make a difference!
Thank you for joining us. Remember to also praise yourself for doing the best you can do.
This tip is about helping your children when someone dies.
Losing a loved one is painful for everyone, including children.
Children may feel overwhelmed and upset when someone dies.
Talking to your children about death can be hard, but it will help them make sense of what is happening.
‚ñ∂Ô∏èPress play 3Ô∏è‚É£ tips on how to help your children when someone dies:
1Ô∏è‚É£ **BE CLEAR**
2Ô∏è‚É£ **ACCEPT FEELINGS**
3Ô∏è‚É£ **SAY GOODBYE**
Here are 3Ô∏è‚É£ tips on how to help your children when someone dies:
In simple words, tell them the person has died and will not come back.
If one of their caregivers has died, tell children who they will live with and who will look after them ‚Äì they often worry about this.
There is no right way for a child to react to loss. Children may act happy but still feel sad.
Listen to your child and tell them whatever you are feeling is okay.
Do something together to say goodbye to the person ‚Äì a song, letter or prayer.
Let us understand how children of different ages react to death.
Small children under the age of 5 years may ask if the person who has died is coming back.
They might hold onto you or other caregivers more or start doing things they used to do when they were younger, like wetting the bed.
Older children between 6 and 11 years old may ask more questions and want to understand what happened.
They may show their grief through anger and experience physical aches or pains.
Adolescents and young teenagers from around the age of 12 years will wonder about why things happen.
Their reactions will vary and can include lack of interest, anger, extreme sadness and poor concentration.
Thank you for joining us. Parenting is full of difficult conversations. Take a moment to care for yourself.
This tip is about protecting our children from sexual violence and responding to it.
During difficult times, children are more likely to face dangers like sexual violence.
Sexual violence means doing or trying to do something sexual to someone that they don‚Äôt want to happen.
This can include things like threatening, pressuring or forcing someone to have sex, or touching them in a sexual way.
Sexual violence can be committed by a stranger, a friend, or even a family member.
‚ñ∂Ô∏èPress play to learn 6Ô∏è‚É£ tips for protecting your child from sexual violence:
1Ô∏è‚É£ **NO IS OK!**
2Ô∏è‚É£ **TELL A PERSON OF TRUST**
3Ô∏è‚É£ **RECOGNIZE**
4Ô∏è‚É£ **LISTEN**
5Ô∏è‚É£ **RESPOND**
6Ô∏è‚É£ **COMFORT YOUR CHILD**
Here are 6Ô∏è‚É£ tips for protecting your child from sexual violence:
Teach your child that no one has the right to touch them or make them uncomfortable.
Practice saying "NO" loudly and strongly together.
Remember, you can do this with words and with body.
Talking about this with your child helps protect them.
Tell your children that abusers often trick by giving gifts, pretending to be kind and supportive. Once violence happens, the abuser asks them to keep sexual violence a ‚Äúsecret‚Äù.
Remind them that they don‚Äôt have to keep secrets from their parents or a person they trust.
Tell your children they don‚Äôt need to feel ashamed about the violence they survived.
Let them know it‚Äôs always okay to talk to a trusted adult, like a parent or a teacher, if someone makes them feel uncomfortable.
It‚Äôs not always easy to see, but some signs may show a child has been hurt:
üîµ Start doing things they used to do when they were younger, such as wetting the bed
üîµ Unexplained physical complaints
üîµ Sudden changes in mood or behaviour
üîµ Holding onto you or other caregivers more
üîµ Struggling with peers or school ‚Äî such as having fewer friends, doing worse in class, or skipping school
üîµ Risky or self-harming behaviours, like cutting, stealing, or using substances
Take a deep breath so you can respond calmly.
Ask yourself, ‚ÄúWhat does my child need right now?‚Äù
Let your child share with you what they need. Avoid criticism.
Notice what they are feeling and tell them what you notice so they feel heard.
Tell your child that you believe them and are there for them.
5Ô∏è‚É£ **RESPOND**: What might help what is going on?
You might need to help your child talk about their feelings or redirect their focus.
You might need to talk about the actions that you or your child could take to help with what has happened. In case of sexual violence, you and Your child need to go to the clinic.
Right now, your child needs you to be there for them with love.
Remind them that it is not their fault what other people did to them.
Remember, you can always type {HELP}  and get information about resources in your community where you may receive help.
6Ô∏è‚É£ **COMFORT YOUR CHILD**
It can be hard to see your child feeling upset or confused, but there is a lot you can do to support them.
üíö Reassure them it‚Äôs not their fault and they are safe and loved.
üéà Remind your child again that you love them and that together, you two will find solutions. Thank them for sharing with you.
Thank you for joining us. Talking about sexual violence with your children will go a long way to protect them. It is not easy but necessary. They are lucky to have you. Be proud of yourself.
Keeping children safe can feel overwhelming, especially when dealing with unexpected challenges.
text: In such moments, having a clear plan will help you and your children know what to do to be safe.

SourceText: In such moments, having a clear plan will help you and your children know what to do to be safe.
Press Play ‚ñ∂Ô∏è to learn 3Ô∏è‚É£ tips on how to keep your children safe in an unsafe situation:
1Ô∏è‚É£ **TALK**
2Ô∏è‚É£ **PLAN**
3Ô∏è‚É£ **ASSURE**
Here are 3Ô∏è‚É£ tips on how to keep your children safe in an unsafe situation:
Talk to children about what is happening in a way that they can understand.
Talk to them about things that are not safe.
Identify a meeting point and make a plan in case you get separated.
Keep children with you or with someone you trust all the time.
Planning with children helps them feel safer too.
Assure your children that you will do everything to keep them safe.
Encourage them to share anything that worries them with you.
Be proud of your efforts and try to take care of yourself too.
Thank you for joining us. Remember that you are not alone and that there are things you can do to keep your children safe.
Having to travel with children during a crisis can feel scary and hard.
When your children see that you're prepared, it can make them feel more stable even when things around them seem uncertain
There are ways to help keep your children away from harm while you are on the move.
Your child will feel reassured knowing you have a plan of action.
Press Play ‚ñ∂Ô∏è to learn 2Ô∏è‚É£ things you can do to ensure that you and your children are as safe as possible when you are travelling in a crisis situation:
1Ô∏è‚É£ **MOVE SAFELY**
2Ô∏è‚É£ **TAKE CARE OF YOURSELF**
Here are 2Ô∏è‚É£ things you can do to ensure that you and your children are as safe as possible when you are travelling in a crisis situation:
Travel with a group of people you know where possible.
If you need to show your passport or ID, try to keep it in your hands.
When it's hard, remember you're trying your best in a difficult situation.
Be sure to look after yourself too.
Thank you for joining us. You are making a difference to the safety of your children.
Human trafficking is when someone is tricked, forced, or pressured into doing something they don‚Äôt want to do for someone else‚Äôs benefit.
This can include being forced to work, commit crimes,  perform sexual acts or anything else that is harmful so the human trafficker can gain money or favours.
It can happen to anyone, anywhere, including in proximity to your own home.
Sometimes, children may not realise that they are being tricked by traffickers. They might be scared to report the adult who is threatening them.
This lesson will help you protect your child by teaching them how to stay safe and what to watch out for.
Press Play ‚ñ∂Ô∏è to learn 5Ô∏è‚É£ things for you to do to help protect your children from traffickers.
1Ô∏è‚É£ **TEACH YOUR CHILD**
2Ô∏è‚É£ **TRUST THEMSELVES**
3Ô∏è‚É£ **GET AWAY SAFELY**
4Ô∏è‚É£ **TALK TO TRUSTED ADULT**
Ô∏è5Ô∏è‚É£ **TEACH YOURSELF**
Here areÔ∏è 5Ô∏è‚É£ things for you to do to help protect your children from traffickers:
1Ô∏è‚É£ **TEACH YOUR CHILD** what human trafficking is and who traffickers can be.
Traffickers are people who lie or pretend to be friendly to trick children into going with them or doing things they don‚Äôt want to do.
Traffickers can be anyone - men, women, couples, or even someone your child knows and trusts.
They might offer gifts, make big promises, give lots of compliments or ask them to keep a secret to gain trust.
Teach your child to listen to their feelings. If something feels weird or scary, trust your gut ‚Äî your feelings are probably right.
3Ô∏è‚É£ **GET AWAY SAFELY**
Before leaving with anyone, even someone your child knows, tell your child to make sure they feel safe.
Tell your child to make sure someone else knows where they are.
Teach them to not go anywhere with strangers even if they are nice to them.

If they feel unsafe, teach them to stay calm. Walk away if they can, go to a safe place with people around, and ask a trusted adult or authority (like a teacher, police officer, or security guard) for help.
4Ô∏è‚É£ **TALK TO TRUSTED ADULT**
Tell children to talk to a trusted adult if they feel confused or worried.
Let your child know they should tell you or another trusted adult if anyone, even someone they know:
üî¥ gives them gifts
üî¥ makes big promises, or
üî¥ asks them to keep secrets that make them feel uneasy.
Remind them they can always talk to you, no matter what.
5Ô∏è‚É£ **TEACH YOURSELF**
Learn how to spot signs that something might be wrong.
Watch for changes in your child‚Äôs behaviour or mood.
Also look out for if your child is:
üîµ Going to places that are unusual for them
üîµ Getting gifts or money they can‚Äôt explain
üîµ Hiding who they talk to or where they go
üîµ Getting nervous, upset, or secretive when using a phone or going online
These signs don‚Äôt always mean something is wrong but they are good reasons to check in with your children and show them you care
Thank you for joining us today. Talking to children about traffickers can be hard for both you and  your children. Remember to be kind and patient with yourself and your children.
Being in a shelter can be lonely and stressful for children.
There are things you already know how to do, like doing daily activities and practising self-care. These can help you and your children feel safe and secure in a new place.
Press Play ‚ñ∂Ô∏è to learn 3Ô∏è‚É£ new tips that will help you to support your children in a shelter:
1Ô∏è‚É£ **MAKE IT FAMILIAR**
2Ô∏è‚É£ **FIND THE POSITIVE**
3Ô∏è‚É£ **REASSURE**
Here are 3Ô∏è‚É£ new tips that will help you to support your children in a shelter:
If possible,take a comfort item from home with them to a shelter
Decorate the shelter together, with notes or pictures for the walls if you can.
Find something to smile about together.
Share one good thing that happened at the end of each day with your child - no matter how small.
Try to reassure your children as often as you can.
For younger children, you may want to give them a hug or hold them when they are feeling scared.
For older children, let them know that you are here for them and give them the space to talk to you.
Thank you for joining us.  Remember that your children learn from you, so taking good care of yourself every day will help them take care of themselves too. You can do it!
In times of crisis, children may carry big worries. If they are also being bullied at school or nearby, it can hurt their well-being.
This lesson will help you notice signs of bullying & support your child with care.
Even in difficult times, your support can help your child feel safe and strong. üíõ
Press Play ‚ñ∂Ô∏è to learn 5Ô∏è‚É£things you can do to help your child stay safe from harm:
1Ô∏è‚É£ **SPEND ONE-ON-ONE TIME**
2Ô∏è‚É£ **EXPLAIN BULLYING**
3Ô∏è‚É£ **NOTICE PHYSICAL CHANGES**
4Ô∏è‚É£ **NOTICE EMOTIONAL CHANGES**
5Ô∏è‚É£ **RESPOND WITH CARE**
Here are 5Ô∏è‚É£ things you can do to help your child stay safe from harm:
The more time you spend together, the easier it is for your child to speak up.
üó£Ô∏è Ask how their day was
‚ù§Ô∏è Ask how they‚Äôre feeling
üìÖ Make one-on-one time a habit
ü§ó Listen without rushing
üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Remind them they can always come to you
Children can speak up when they understand bullying.
üìö Teach them it means hurting someone on purpose
üí¨ Talk about words, actions, and online harm
üß≠ Say it can happen to anyone
üó£Ô∏è Encourage them to speak up
üß° Let them know you‚Äôre there
Children might not talk about bullying, but their body can show signs.
Keep an eye out for:
ü§ï Unexplained bruises or cuts
üëïDamaged clothes or school supplies
ü§í Complaining of headaches or stomach aches
üò¥ Trouble sleeping
üçΩÔ∏è Eating much more or much less than usual
Bullying can affect how your child feels on the inside. Watch for changes in mood or behavior like:
üò¢ Sudden sadness, anger, or mood swings
üòü Acting nervous, scared, or worried a lot
üôÅ Saying things like ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my fault‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not good enough‚Äù
üö∂‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Wanting to be alone more than usual
üò∂ Quietness or not wanting to talk
üè´ Avoiding school or social activities they used to enjoy
5Ô∏è‚É£ **RESPOND WITH CARE**
If your child shares something that worries you, how you respond matters.
üíôTake a pause and stay calm, even if you feel upset
üëÇ Listen without interrupting or blaming
üëç Believe what your child tells you
üí¨ Say things like ‚ÄúThank you for telling me‚Äù or ‚ÄúYou did the right thing‚Äù
üìù Write down what happened or take screenshots if it happened online
üßë‚Äçüè´ Report to the school or youth worker to get support
Thank you for taking time to learn how to notice signs of bullying and respond with care.  Children feel safer and stronger when they know someone is there for them.
If the bullying is serious or ongoing, get support from a teacher, school counselor, or local child protection team. You are not alone.
In hard times, children often use phones or the internet to play, learn, or talk to others. But sometimes, children can also be bullied online.
They might send hurtful messages, share embarrassing pictures, or pretend to be someone else.
This can make children feel scared, sad, or alone.
You can‚Äôt always stop it, but you can look out for the signs and help your child feel safe and supported.
Press Play ‚ñ∂Ô∏è to learn 6Ô∏è‚É£ things you can do to help your child stay safe from online harm:
1Ô∏è‚É£ **BE INVOLVED EARLY**
2Ô∏è‚É£ **MAKE RULES TOGETHER**
3Ô∏è‚É£ **USE PRIVACY SETTINGS**
4Ô∏è‚É£ **TALK ABOUT ONLINE BULLYING**
Ô∏è5Ô∏è‚É£ **KNOW THE SIGNS**
6Ô∏è‚É£ **TAKE ACTION TOGETHER**
Here are 6Ô∏è‚É£ things you can do to help your child stay safe from online harm:
‚è±Ô∏èSpend time online with your child, especially when they‚Äôre young.
‚ùìAsk what they like to do and who they talk to.
üíõShow them they can always come to you..
üí¨Talk about how long they can use the phone and which apps are okay.
‚ùåTell them not to share their name, school, or photos with strangers.
Help them:
‚úÖMake their profile private
‚úÖBlock or report mean people
‚úÖHide or delete posts
‚úÖChoose who can send messages or see their posts
Taking control helps your child feel safer and more confident online.
Tell your child that some people use the internet to be mean or hurt others on purpose.
üì±It can happen in messages, games, or social media.
üíöLet your child know it‚Äôs never their fault‚Äîand they can always come to you for help.
‚≠êHelp your child understand it‚Äôs okay to walk away, block, or ask an adult for support.
5Ô∏è‚É£ **KNOW THE SIGNS**
If your child is being bullied online, your child may feel too scared or ashamed to tell you.
Here are some signs to watch for:
üü°Avoiding friends or family
üì±Hiding the screen or using the internet less (or more)
üè´Skipping school or fun activities
üò£Sudden feelings sadness, anger, or worry
üî¥Talks about harming themselves
üíôIf your child tells you someone is being mean online, praise them for speaking up. For example, you can say: ‚ÄúYou did the right thing. We‚Äôll handle this together.‚Äù
üì±Don‚Äôt take away their phone‚Äîit can make them feel worse.
üí¨Save messages or screenshots as proof.
‚ùåHelp them block the person and report it on the app.
üö®If the harm continues, contact the police or a support line.
Thank you for taking time to learn how to protect your child online.  You don‚Äôt need to be a tech expert‚Äîyour love, support, and small actions make a big difference.
And if you ever feel unsure, it‚Äôs okay to ask someone you trust for help or type HELP in CrisisText.
Before we begin, let's take a pause together. Remember, this is something you can do whenever you are feeling stressed.
Today's pause is called "Breath and Body Awareness".
Press ‚ñ∂Ô∏è to watch a video to practise taking a pause together
Press ‚ñ∂Ô∏è to listen to an audio and practise taking a pause together
Thank you for taking a moment to pause with us. It's time for today's lesson.
Today's pause is called "Body Scan".
Before we begin, let's take a pause together.
Sometimes when we are experiencing stress or feeling alone, it can be helpful to send thoughts of loving kindness to ourselves.
Today's pause is called "Loving Kindness Meditation".
Take a moment to reflect on your experience.
When you are ready, continue to today's lesson with a sense of calm.
Thank you for taking a moment to pause with us.
